elements.content: 2-Phosphaphenol (L) forms unusual complexes with copper and gold halides. With CuCl, a dimeric [L2CuCl]2 complex is observed with L acting both as η1-P terminal and μ2-P bridging ligand and a copper–copper short contact of 2.549 Å. With copper bromide, a distorted infinite chain [L2CuBr] n is formed, whereas with copper iodide, the zigzag chain [L2CuI] n is observed. The phosphaphenol acts as a terminal ligand coating the CuX molecular wires. With gold chloride, a dimeric [LAuCl]2 complex is formed, which is held by an aurophilic interaction at 3.132 Å.
elements.clean_text: 2-Phosphaphenol (L) forms unusual complexes with copper and gold halides. With CuCl, a dimeric [L2CuCl]2 complex is observed with L acting both as η1-P terminal and μ2-P bridging ligand and a copper-copper short contact of 2.549 Å. With copper bromide, a distorted infinite chain [L2CuBr] n  is formed, whereas with copper iodide, the zigzag chain [L2CuI] n  is observed. The phosphaphenol acts as a terminal ligand coating the CuX molecular wires. With gold chloride, a dimeric [LAuCl]2 complex is formed, which is held by an aurophilic interaction at 3.132 Å.

elements.content: Phosphinines are known for the variety of complexes that they are able to give with transition metals and for the sensitivity of their coordination modes to their substitution pattern. After the discovery of the parent 2-phosphaphenol, it was logical to start an investigation of its coordination chemistry. The choice of copper­(I) halides was dictated by the huge structural variety of their complexes. The recent discovery that phosphinines are able to stabilize gold nanoparticles also led us to perform a preliminary investigation of a 2-phosphaphenol gold complex. Our work was rewarded by a crop of original structures that are reported hereafter.
elements.clean_text: Phosphinines are known for the variety of complexes that they are able to give with transition metals and for the sensitivity of their coordination modes to their substitution pattern. After the discovery of the parent 2-phosphaphenol, it was logical to start an investigation of its coordination chemistry. The choice of copper(I) halides was dictated by the huge structural variety of their complexes. The recent discovery that phosphinines are able to stabilize gold nanoparticles also led us to perform a preliminary investigation of a 2-phosphaphenol gold complex. Our work was rewarded by a crop of original structures that are reported hereafter.

elements.content: Several complexes of copper halides with phosphinines have been described in the literature. In most cases, they imply phosphinine macrocycles or multidentate ligands with one or several phosphinines. In one case, the copper halide complex of a simple phosphinine has been structurally characterized. It shows a stairlike structure where each copper atom is linked to three iodine atoms and one phosphorus. The phosphinine acts as a η1-P ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Several complexes of copper halides with phosphinines have been described in the literature. In most cases, they imply phosphinine macrocycles or multidentate ligands with one or several phosphinines. In one case, the copper halide complex of a simple phosphinine has been structurally characterized. It shows a stairlike structure where each copper atom is linked to three iodine atoms and one phosphorus. The phosphinine acts as a η1-P ligand.

elements.content: Although it contains a hydroxyl group which modulates the reactivity of phosphorus, 2-phosphaphenol 1 still acts as a pure phosphorus ligand in our case. The reaction with copper­(I) chloride in dichloromethane is almost instantaneous at room temperature (eq ).
elements.clean_text: Although it contains a hydroxyl group which modulates the reactivity of phosphorus, 2-phosphaphenol 1 still acts as a pure phosphorus ligand in our case. The reaction with copper(I) chloride in dichloromethane is almost instantaneous at room temperature (eq ). 1

elements.content: Complex 2 was characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis (Figure ). The dimeric structure contains two η1-P and two μ2-P phosphinines. To the best of our knowledge, only two complexes with a phosphinine acting as a μ2-P ligand have been described in the literature. The structures of the two types of rings are remarkably similar. In solution, a fast dynamic equilibrium takes place, since only one set of resonances is observed at room temperature for the phosphinine in the 31P and 13C NMR spectra. Electrospray mass spectrometry detects the intact dimer in acetonitrile at m/z 643.8281. Partial decoalescence was observed in the 31P spectrum at −100 °C in dichloromethane. The coordination sphere of copper is a slightly distorted tetrahedron. The copper–copper distance at 2.549 Å is shorter than the sum of the covalent radii of Cu (1.40 Å) and indicates a copper–copper interaction. The planes of all four phosphinines are perpendicular to the Cu2P2 core. With copper­(I) bromide and iodide, the course of the reaction is completely different (eq ).
elements.clean_text: Complex 2 was characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis (Figure ). The dimeric structure contains two η1-P and two μ2-P phosphinines. To the best of our knowledge, only two complexes with a phosphinine acting as a μ2-P ligand have been described in the literature. The structures of the two types of rings are remarkably similar. In solution, a fast dynamic equilibrium takes place, since only one set of resonances is observed at room temperature for the phosphinine in the 31P and 13C NMR spectra. Electrospray mass spectrometry detects the intact dimer in acetonitrile at m/z 643.8281. Partial decoalescence was observed in the 31P spectrum at -100 °C in dichloromethane. The coordination sphere of copper is a slightly distorted tetrahedron. The copper-copper distance at 2.549 Å is shorter than the sum of the covalent radii of Cu (1.40 Å) and indicates a copper-copper interaction. The planes of all four phosphinines are perpendicular to the Cu2P2 core. With copper(I) bromide and iodide, the course of the reaction is completely different (eq ). 2

elements.content: Both complexes have been characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis (Figures and ). The structures are characterized by isolated X–Cu–X– chains. In the copper iodide chain with a copper···copper distance of 4.081 Å, the flat phosphinine rings stay rigorously parallel. In the case of the copper bromide chain, the copper···copper distance decreases to 4.051 Å and the chain is distorted. The P–Cu···Cu–P torsion angle goes from 0° (P2CuI) to 174° (P1–Cu···Cu–P1) and −62° (P2–Cu···Cu–P2) (P2CuBr), probably in order to reduce steric crowding. Whatever the reason, the formation of these isolated chains is a rare feature. In most cases, several chains are coupled together by bidentate ligands. The copper iodide chain is probably stabilized by π interactions between the parallel aromatic rings (distance 3.593 Å), which act as a layer coating the [CuI] n core. In both cases, electrospray mass spectrometry only detects the monomeric units in acetonitrile at m/z 365.8635 (L2CuBr) and 413.8497 (L2CuI).
elements.clean_text: Both complexes have been characterized by X-ray crystal structure analysis (Figures  and ). The structures are characterized by isolated X-Cu-X- chains. In the copper iodide chain with a copper⋅⋅⋅copper distance of 4.081 Å, the flat phosphinine rings stay rigorously parallel. In the case of the copper bromide chain, the copper⋅⋅⋅copper distance decreases to 4.051 Å and the chain is distorted. The P-Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu-P torsion angle goes from 0° (P2CuI) to 174° (P1-Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu-P1) and -62° (P2-Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu-P2) (P2CuBr), probably in order to reduce steric crowding. Whatever the reason, the formation of these isolated chains is a rare feature. In most cases, several chains are coupled together by bidentate ligands. The copper iodide chain is probably stabilized by π interactions between the parallel aromatic rings (distance 3.593 Å), which act as a layer coating the [CuI] n  core. In both cases, electrospray mass spectrometry only detects the monomeric units in acetonitrile at m/z 365.8635 (L2CuBr) and 413.8497 (L2CuI).

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of the phosphaphenol–copper bromide complex 3. Main distances (Å) and angles (deg): P1–Cu1 = 2.2401(15), P2–Cu1 = 2.2358(16), Cu1–Br1 = 2.5243(9), Cu1–Br1A = 2.5115(8), P1–C1 = 1.735(6), C1–O1 = 1.365(6), C1–C2 = 1.385(7), C2–C3 = 1.395(8), C3–C4 = 1.387(8), C4–C5 = 1.377(8), C5–P = 1.710(6), P2–C6 = 1.740(5), C6–O2 = 1.367(6), C6–C7 = 1.383(8), C7–C8 = 1.379(8), C8–C9 = 1.389(8), C9–C10 = 1.382(8), C10–P2 = 1.717(6); P1–Cu1–Br1 = 110.55(5), P1–Cu1–P2 = 120.92(6), Br1–Cu1–P2 = 108.81(5), Br1–Cu1–Br1A = 102.38(3), C1–P1–C5 = 102.7(3), C6–P2–C10 = 102.6(3).

X-ray crystal structure of the phosphaphenol–copper iodide complex 4. Main distances (Å) and angles (deg): P1–Cu1 = 2.2290(11), Cu1–I1 = 2.6487(4), P1–C1 = 1.741(4), C1–O1 = 1.370(5), C1–C2 = 1.381(6), C2–C3 = 1.389(7), C3–C4 = 1.386(7), C4–C5 = 1.384(6), C5–P = 1.717(5); P1–Cu1–I1 = 105.81(3), P1A–Cu1–P1AB = 113.12(6), I1A–Cu1–I1B = 100.77(2), C1–P1–C5 = 102.9(2).

The case of gold chloride is again different. A few phosphinine–gold complexes have been described in the literature. Classical linear monomeric [LAuCl] and [L2Au]+ complexes have been observed with simple phosphinines. It has been argued that phosphinines, as a result of their low steric demand and strong π-accepting properties, could mimic the coordinating properties of carbon monoxide. What we have observed in our case can give some support to this view (eq ).
elements.clean_text: The case of gold chloride is again different. A few phosphinine-gold complexes have been described in the literature. Classical linear monomeric [LAuCl] and [L2Au]+ complexes have been observed with simple phosphinines. It has been argued that phosphinines, as a result of their low steric demand and strong π-accepting properties, could mimic the coordinating properties of carbon monoxide. What we have observed in our case can give some support to this view (eq ). 3

elements.content: A dimeric structure is observed (Figure ) with an aurophilic interaction at 3.1323(3) Å. Much weaker Au···Au interactions exist in the solid-state structures of [Cl–Au–CO] at 3.38 Å and of [Cl–Au–PEt3] at 3.568 and 3.615 Å. The Au···Au interaction in 5 distorts the linearity of the P–Au–Cl unit, which forms an angle of 170.26(4)°. The two Cl···H hydrogen bonds of ethylmethylimidazolium chloride are found at 1.9272 and 2.6374 Å. Thus, we can guess that the dimeric structure is also probably stabilized by Cl···H hydrogen bonds, since the O–H groups point toward the chlorine atoms with a Cl···H distance of 2.311 Å. The two monomeric units form an angle of 111.77°. Electrospray mass spectrometry detects the intact dimer in acetonitrile at m/z 687.8864, thus confirming its stability.
elements.clean_text: A dimeric structure is observed (Figure ) with an aurophilic interaction at 3.1323(3) Å. Much weaker Au⋅⋅⋅Au interactions exist in the solid-state structures of [Cl-Au-CO] at 3.38 Å and of [Cl-Au-PEt3] at 3.568 and 3.615 Å. The Au⋅⋅⋅Au interaction in 5 distorts the linearity of the P-Au-Cl unit, which forms an angle of 170.26(4)°. The two Cl⋅⋅⋅H hydrogen bonds of ethylmethylimidazolium chloride are found at 1.9272 and 2.6374 Å. Thus, we can guess that the dimeric structure is also probably stabilized by Cl⋅⋅⋅H hydrogen bonds, since the O-H groups point toward the chlorine atoms with a Cl⋅⋅⋅H distance of 2.311 Å. The two monomeric units form an angle of 111.77°. Electrospray mass spectrometry detects the intact dimer in acetonitrile at m/z 687.8864, thus confirming its stability.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of the phosphaphenol–gold chloride complex 5. Main distances (Å) and angles (deg): P1–Au1 = 2.2163(13), Au1–Cl1 = 2.3079(12), Au1–Au1A = 3.1323(3), P1–C5 = 1.731(5), C5–O1 = 1.358(6), P1–C1 = 1.716(5), C1–C2 = 1.388(8), C2–C3 = 1.382(8), C3–C4 = 1.385(8), C4–C5 = 1.393(7); P1–Au1–Cl1 = 170.26(4), P1–Au1–Au1A = 110.92(3), Cl1–Au1–Au1A = 78.42(3), C1–P1–C5 = 105.4(2).

This work clearly demonstrates that 1 has unusual coordinating properties. We hope that they will translate into interesting catalytic and electronic applications.

Experimental Section

All reactions were performed under nitrogen using solvents purified and dried by standard methods. NMR spectra were obtained using JEOL ECA 400, Bruker AV400, and Bruker AV300 spectrometers. MS spectra were obtained in ESI negative mode on a Thermo Finnigan LCQ DECA XP MAX instrument. Commercial reagents were used without further purification. X-ray crystallographic analyses were performed on a Bruker X8 APEX CCD diffractometer or a Bruker Kappa CCD diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
This work clearly demonstrates that 1 has unusual coordinating properties. We hope that they will translate into interesting catalytic and electronic applications.

Experimental Section

All reactions were performed under nitrogen using solvents purified and dried by standard methods. NMR spectra were obtained using JEOL ECA 400, Bruker AV400, and Bruker AV300 spectrometers. MS spectra were obtained in ESI negative mode on a Thermo Finnigan LCQ DECA XP MAX instrument. Commercial reagents were used without further purification. X-ray crystallographic analyses were performed on a Bruker X8 APEX CCD diffractometer or a Bruker Kappa CCD diffractometer.

elements.content: To a stirred solution of phosphaphenol 1 (35 mg, 0.3 mmol) in dichloromethane (8 mL) was added CuCl (30 mg, 0.3 mmol) at room temperature. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min, 31P NMR confirmed that the starting material had disappeared. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated. The resulting solid was washed with hexane to give the desired complex 2 as a yellow solid. Single crystals were obtained by diffusion of hexane into dichloromethane (50 mg, 93%). 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 114.9. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.34–7.36 (m, 1H, CH), 7.46–7.55 (m, 2H, CH), 8.18–8.29 (m, 1H, CH), 8.93 (br-s, 1H, OH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 124.51 (d, J CP = 4.9 Hz, CH), 129.18 (d, J CP = 18.6 Hz, CH), 132.97 (d, J CP = 20.9 Hz, CH), 145.37 (d, 1 J CP = 5.9 Hz, CH), 183.59 (d, 1 J CP = 5.6 Hz, CP). HRMS: m/z 642.8215 (calcd for C20H19O4P4 63Cu2Cl2 642.8203).

Synthesis of Compounds 2-5 

To a stirred solution of phosphaphenol 1 (35 mg, 0.3 mmol) in dichloromethane (8 mL) was added CuCl (30 mg, 0.3 mmol) at room temperature. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min, 31P NMR confirmed that the starting material had disappeared. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated. The resulting solid was washed with hexane to give the desired complex 2 as a yellow solid. Single crystals were obtained by diffusion of hexane into dichloromethane (50 mg, 93%). 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 114.9. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.34-7.36 (m, 1H, CH), 7.46-7.55 (m, 2H, CH), 8.18-8.29 (m, 1H, CH), 8.93 (br-s, 1H, OH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 124.51 (d, J CP = 4.9 Hz, CH), 129.18 (d, J CP = 18.6 Hz, CH), 132.97 (d, J CP = 20.9 Hz, CH), 145.37 (d, 1 J CP = 5.9 Hz, CH), 183.59 (d, 1 J CP = 5.6 Hz, CP). elements.content: The synthesis of 3 was identical with that of 1, with CuCl replaced by CuBr (43 mg, 0.3 mmol). Recrystallization (CH2Cl2/hexane) afforded 3 (50 mg, 90%) as a yellow solid. 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 110.7. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.32–7.37 (m, 1H, CH), 7.45–7.56 (m, 2H, CH), 8.15–8.26 (m, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 124.44 (d, J CP = 4.8 Hz, CH), 129.38 (d, J CP = 18.5 Hz, CH), 132.98 (d, J CP = 20.9 Hz, CH), 145.37 (d, 1 J CP = 3.6 Hz, CH), 183.59 (d, 1 J CP = 2.9 Hz, CP). HRMS: m/z 367.8605 (calcd for C10H10O2P2 65CuBr 367.8617, monomer).

Recrystallization (CH2Cl2/hexane) afforded 4 (82 mg, 88%) as a yellow solid. 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 120.7. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.33–7.38 (m, 1H, CH), 7.45–7.57 (m, 2H, CH), 8.19–8.30 (m, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 123.77 (d, J CP = 5.8 Hz, CH), 129.11 (d, J CP = 18.4 Hz, CH), 132.58 (d, J CP = 20.2 Hz, CH), 145.37 (d, J CP = 12.0 Hz, CH), 183.59 (d, 1 J CP = 11.1 Hz, CP). HRMS: m/z 413.8513 (calcd for C10H10O2P2CuI 413.8497, monomer).

Recrystallization (CH2Cl2/hexane) afforded 5 (82 mg, 95%) as a yellow solid. 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 142.0. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.27–7.65 (m, 3H, CH), 8.21–8.33 (m, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 124.58 (d, J CP = 4.8 Hz, CH), 129.13 (d, J CP = 18.2 Hz, CH), 133.02 (d, J CP = 20.1 Hz, CH), 147.14 (d, 1 J CP = 10.5 Hz, CH), 186.39 (d, 1 J CP = 9.6 Hz, CP). HRMS: m/z 686.8760 (calcd for C10H9O2P2Au2Cl2 686.8786).

To a stirred solution of phosphaphenol 1 (35 mg, 0.3 mmol) in dichloromethane (8 mL) was added CuCl (30 mg, 0.3 mmol) at room temperature. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min, 31P NMR confirmed that the starting material had disappeared. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated. The resulting solid was washed with hexane to give the desired complex 2 as a yellow solid. The synthesis of 3 was identical with that of 1, with CuCl replaced by CuBr (43 mg, 0.3 mmol). Recrystallization (CH2Cl2/hexane) afforded 3 (50 mg, 90%) as a yellow solid. 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 110.7. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.32-7.37 (m, 1H, CH), 7.45-7.56 (m, 2H, CH), 8.15-8.26 (m, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 124.44 (d, J CP = 4.8 Hz, CH), 129.38 (d, J CP = 18.5 Hz, CH), 132.98 (d, J CP = 20.9 Hz, CH), 145.37 (d, 1 J CP = 3.6 Hz, CH), 183.59 (d, 1 J CP = 2.9 Hz, CP). HRMS: m/z 367.8605 (calcd for C10H10O2P2 65CuBr 367.8617, monomer).

The synthesis of 4 was identical with that of 2 (50 mg, 0.45 mmol), with CuCl replaced by CuI (85 mg, 0.45 mmol). Recrystallization (CH2Cl2/hexane) afforded 4 (82 mg, 88%) as a yellow solid. 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 120.7. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.33-7.38 (m, 1H, CH), 7.45-7.57 (m, 2H, CH), 8.19-8.30 (m, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 123.77 (d, J CP = 5.8 Hz, CH), 129.11 (d, J CP = 18.4 Hz, CH), 132.58 (d, J CP = 20.2 Hz, CH), 145.37 (d, J CP = 12.0 Hz, CH), 183.59 (d, 1 J CP = 11.1 Hz, CP). HRMS: m/z 413.8513 (calcd for C10H10O2P2CuI 413.8497, monomer).

The synthesis of 5 was identical with that of 1 (50 mg, 0.45 mmol), with CuCl replaced by AuCl (105 mg, 0.45 mmol). Recrystallization (CH2Cl2/hexane) afforded 5 (82 mg, 95%) as a yellow solid. 31P NMR (CDCl3): δ 142.0. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.27-7.65 (m, 3H, CH), 8.21-8.33 (m, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 124.58 (d, J CP = 4.8 Hz, CH), 129.13 (d, J CP = 18.2 Hz, CH), 133.02 (d, J CP = 20.1 Hz, CH), 147.14 (d, 1 J CP = 10.5 Hz, CH), 186.39 (d, 1 J CP = 9.6 Hz, CP). HRMS: m/z 686.8760 (calcd for C10H9O2P2Au2Cl2 686.8786).

with Copper(I) and Gold(I) Halides
